Award.AwardTitle: Local and Traditional Knowledge and the Role of Storytelling in Building and Sustaining Resilience in African American and Alaska Native communities
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support a workshop to explore community resilience in the face of social and environmental change. The PI and research team from Oberlin College proposes to do this through a participatory methodology that creates a collaboration between community members from Africatown (Plateau), Alabama and Utqiagvik (Barrow), Alaska and the Oberlin research team. It is the research teams' thesis that the transmission of knowledge, inter-generationally, is key to long-term community resilience in response to rapid environmental and social change. Among African American communities, represented in this workshop by the residents of Africatown, this knowledge transmission often takes the form of storytelling and among Alaska Native communities, represented by residents of Utqiagvik, this transmission is of Traditional Knowledge. By understanding the relationship between resilience and storytelling and traditional knowledge the research team proposes that community can be strengthened even when facing extreme environmental events such as, sea level rise and storm surge flooding or social, economic, and technological events such as, job loss due to globalization or the BP oil spill. It is the idea of the research team that by collaborating closely with the communities in co-producing knowledge through this workshop on resilience in the face of rapid change they will be able to identify key elements of the social and cultural systems that can ensure the long-term health and well-being of many communities.

Although Africatown and Utqiagvik are geographically disparate communities they share similar challenges to their resilience in response to environmental and social-economic change. The PIs will hold the workshop in Africatown, Alabama that will train local community members and their collaborators from Utqiagvik, Alaska in social science methods and practices. The Samuel Proctor Oral History Program at the University of Florida has been engaged to train all workshop participants, including Oberlin students and researchers, in best practices, methods, and ethics of community oral history, storytelling and traditional knowledge. Using a model of knowledge co-production in science, community members and researchers will work together to define the research questions, choose the methodologies, and create the analytic framework that will ultimately be turned into a long-term, community based research project. Undergraduate students from Oberlin College will participate in trainings and in the ongoing work of oral history. In recruiting students, the research team has particularly focused on students underrepresented in STEM, including students of color, women, and first-generation college students. The conference will highlight how local knowledge embedded in oral history and cultural traditions can offer responses to contemporary challenges.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the support of an NSF conference grant from the Arctic Social Sciences Program, Oberlin College, Iñupiaq Elders from Utqiaġvik, Alaska, and the community of Africatown, Alabama hosted a two-day community oral history workshop at the historic Union Baptist Church in October 2017. Africatown, Alabama is the location where the last ship of enslaved people landed in the U.S. in 1860, brought from West Africa by the ship Clotilda. Clotilda descendants still live in the area today and actively claim and reclaim their sense of place through environmental education and activism. Since the second-half of the nineteenth century, Utqiaġvik and Africatown have been respectively facing challenges of environmental justice, and also have rich storytelling traditions that enable intergenerational transfer of knowledge that enables social resilience in the face of environmental change that often incurs external stress and emotional trauma. This workshop brought two culturally and historically distinct, geographically distant communities together to explore the narratives of environment and social justice. More broadly, through this comparative and collaborative project, we explored the impact of environmental change on, and cultural integrity of, underrepresented and underserved communities.

 

More than 50 participants attended the community history workshop. The members included Africatown residents (Elders, youth, activists, pastors, and community members), Iñupiaq environmentalists, and Oberlin College faculty, staff, and students. The oral history training, provided by the Samuel Proctor Center at the University of Florida, covered topics including: introduction to archival oral history; an overview of the Center’s work and examples of the Center’s projects; a discussion of accessibility and public engagement in oral history work; examples of research products and outputs accessible to communities. Skills training included: methods and best practices; equipment and recording practices; demonstration and discussion of interviews.

 

In addition to presentations and skills-building, the oral history conference began with a visioning session and open discussion/brainstorming that enabled community members to articulate key questions for inquiry at the workshop and in collaborative and reciprocal future research. Africatown community members discussed the importance of oral history to the community as well as sharing stories about the impact of segregation. During dinner, Iñupiaq Elders discussed environmental issues facing their communities and engaged in a storytelling exchange.

 

Since the conference, Oberlin students have returned many times to Africatown and have completed more than 30 interviews with Elders. Our conversations has included the importance of the Mobile County Training School as a sanctuary during Reconstruction and Jim Crow; food practices and subsistence; history, resilience, and reparations. A highlight was the attendance of three students at the 50th reunion of the Mobile County Training School class of 1968. Students participated in the celebration and conducted interviews with alumni who had organized the first prom in a downtown hotel following desegregation. These interviews are transcribed and then posted to the Africatown Digital Archive.

 

Most recently, four students from Oberlin College (who are ongoing collaborators on the Africatown project) participated in the 7th Annual HBCU Climate Conference in New Orleans, Louisiana, hosted by the Deep South Center for Environmental Justice. Students attended the four-day conference, presented their research in a plenary session, and exhibited their poster, "Environmental Justice and Local Knowledge in Africatown, Alabama.” Oberlin students described their work for this project as interviewers, videographers, transcribers, and web designers of the Africatown Digital Archive. The poster was recognized with a third place award among 51 excellent submissions.

 

Involvement in collaborative community-based learning and research with this unique and historically significant community has been a transformative experience for students: it supports their development as engaged researchers; informs their understanding of the ethics of community-scholar partnerships; offers unique opportunities for mentoring by faculty, peers, and community members; and involves them in the co-production of knowledge. This project values the knowledge that community historians hold and their role as mentors of students. This was evident at the conference where Africatown community members and Oberlin students attended and warmly supported each other's presentations.
